ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I absolutely loved learning about all the material discussed in this course. The readings got me thinking about every aspect of public health and the HIV/AIDS epidemic. Professor Bazell is incredibly knowledgeable and an invaluable resource.

I gained a deeper appreciation and understanding of evaluating the history of science and medicine. I gained a through understanding of the HIV/AIDS pandemic, from both a scientific and sociopolitical stance. I also gained experience in reading critical journal articles from policy, public health, and basic science sectors.

This class taught me a lot about more intricacies of the sociopolitical history of HIV/AIDS. I thought I knew a good amount when picking the class, but it turns out that there's so much more to learn.
This class taught me important issues regarding HIV/AIDS from multiple perspectives and communities.

Knowledge on viruses, viral tranmission, molecular structure of said viruses and antiretrovirals, the political history of the HIV/AIDS crisis and its impact on international government and public health policies. Insight into how to read medical journals, and how to write an op-ed
A fundamental understanding of HIV as well as a history of its politicization and a basic understanding of immunology, virology and public health.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths -> The size of the class is conducive to good discussions. Professor Bazell is incredibly knowledgeable and a great resource to have throughout the course. Content is delivered in a variety of formats, from lectures to readings to documentaries. The content of the class is also quite interesting. 

Weakness -> I wish the class had slightly more time for discussion between students.

Strengths: Prof. Bazell is really receptive to student feedback and open to changing the way the course is run based on wishes of students. Comprehensive covering of HIV/AIDS

Weaknesses: Very loosely structured class if organization is something big to you
The course was strong in the topics it covered, and the overall flow of the course. A more discussion-focused seminar could make this class stronger.

Strengths: a great bridge between STEM and the humanities, the class was very much driven by student input (we'd review texts, videos, reports and then come to class discussing what was most prominent to us). Because of this, I think we were able to explore sensitive topics in a careful way
Weakness: N/A
our reading material and other sources were very strong. I think there was a bit of confusion about the quizzes and how they fit into the course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to students in need of a science credit for their distributional requirements under the condition that the student is truly interested in the class's topic.

Yes, especially if they are interested in the history of science and society. It is quite an interesting delve into the AIDS epidemic and its implications that go on today. Especially in the COVID-19 era, I think this course taught a lot of applicable material!
Yes! If you need a science credit, this is a REALLY good option for people who want to learn more about queer history, aren't very good with STEM, or are interested in HIV/AIDs.
Yes, this course taught me important issues that I intend on continuing to learn about in the future.

I would recommend this course to students who are willing to have their preconceived notions about the HIV/AIDS crisis challenged; students who are interested in LGBTQ+ activism in the past century; students who are interested in looking towards the future and how the international community will handle HIV/AIDS in the next century.

Absolutely. The course moved at a engaging pace. we read interesting and important material. and the course blends the scientific with the political aspects of a very important disease so those who are and aren't scientifically minded can be engaged.
